articles.title: Reference
articles.contents:
Websites
Andrenoi. M., (2021, June 2). Coronavirus in Brazil: What You Need to Know. The New York Times. https://www.nytimes.com/article/brazil-coronavirus-cases.html
Our Data in World. (2021). owid. https://github.com/owid/covid-19-data/tree/master/public/data
R-packages
Hao Zhu (2021). kableExtra: Construct Complex Table with ‘kable’ and Pipe Syntax. R package version 1.3.4. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=kableExtra
JJ Allaire, Rich Iannone, Alison Presmanes Hill and Yihui Xie (2021). distill: ‘R Markdown’ Format for Scientific and Technical Writing. R package version 1.2. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=distill
Ramnath Vaidyanathan, Kent Russell and Gareth Watts (2016). sparkline: ‘jQuery’ Sparkline ‘htmlwidget’. R package version 2.0. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=sparkline
Wickham et al., (2019). Welcome to the tidyverse. Journal of Open Source Software, 4(43), 1686, https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01686
Yihui Xie (2021). knitr: A General-Purpose Package for Dynamic Report Generation in R. R package version 1.33.
Yihui Xie, Joe Cheng and Xianying Tan (2021). DT: A Wrapper of the JavaScript Library ‘DataTables’. R package version 0.18. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=DT

articles.title: Analysis
articles.contents:
Data Description
The original COVID-19 and vaccination data is obtained from Our World in Data. The data is then filtered and cleaned so that it is ready for further exploration.
The variables included in the data are:






Table 1: Variable description for owid COVID-19 data


Variable


Description


location


Country of focus


date


Date presented as Date type data


year


Year, extracted from date to enable the convenience of further exploration


month


Month, extracted from date to enable the convenience of further exploration


day


Date, extracted from date


total_cases


Cumulative count of confirmed cases


new_cases


Cases confirmed on daily basis


total_deaths


Cumulative count of confirmed deaths


new_deaths


Deaths confirmed on daily basis


total_vaccinations


Total vaccinations administered


people_vaccinated


People that received at least one dose


people_fully_vaccinated


People that received all doses prescribed confirmed as fully vaccinated


population


Population of target country


Note: 


 Data collected from Our World in Data












Exploration

<\/thead>\n<\/table>","options":{"pageLength":8,"fnDrawCallback":"function(){HTMLWidgets.staticRender();}","columnDefs":[{"className":"dt-right","targets":[3,4,5]},{"orderable":false,"targets":0}],"order":[],"autoWidth":false,"orderClasses":false,"orderCellsTop":true,"lengthMenu":[8,10,25,50,100]}},"evals":["options.fnDrawCallback"],"jsHooks":[]}
The table offers a brief overview of how the number of confirmed cases and deaths fluctuated over 2020 to current, it also implies that Brazil started it’s vaccination process on Jan 2021. We can see that the growth of total vaccinations administered is slowing down on late Feb 2021, which is only about one month after vaccination released. The trend is then steady after Mar 2021.
The question is, did the vaccination controls the outbreak of COVID-19 in Brazil? Examining the case growth rate you may discover that there’s little short-term influence of vaccination in restraining the COVID-19 confirmed cases and deaths, that the daily case & death growth is still fluctuating with various peaks presents.

 Source: Our World in Data


The summary statistics demonstrated straightforwardly that Brazil did not achieve a huge improve on controlling the spread of COVID-19 infection even after the vaccinations with 62.86 % of people vaccinated with at least one dose. It is common knowledge that it may take times for vaccine to take effect in controlling the spread, but how did Brazil’s situation keep deteriorating that the maximum daily confirmed case in 2021 is much higher than 2021?
Manuela Andrenoi in The New York Times reveals that “…with efforts by state governments to combat the virus often at odds with the positions adopted by the president, who pressured public health officials to do away with social distancing recommendations, calling Covid-19 a”measly cold“.”, with two health ministers left after clashes with president Mr.Bolsonaro. The chaos of both politically and socially ultimately results in Brazil’s dilemma.
